review.title: On Valid Optimal Assignment Kernels and Applications to Graph Classification
review.abstract: The success of kernel methods has initiated the design of novel positive semidefinite functions, in particular for structured data. A leading design paradigm for this is the convolution kernel, which decomposes structured objects into their parts and sums over all pairs of parts. Assignment kernels, in contrast, are obtained from an optimal bijection between parts, which can provide a more valid notion of similarity. In general however, optimal assignments yield indefinite functions, which complicates their use in kernel methods. We characterize a class of base kernels used to compare parts that guarantees positive semidefinite optimal assignment kernels. These base kernels give rise to hierarchies from which the optimal assignment kernels are computed in linear time by histogram intersection. We apply these results by developing the Weisfeiler-Lehman optimal assignment kernel for graphs. It provides high classification accuracy on widely-used benchmark data sets improving over the original Weisfeiler-Lehman kernel.

metadata.title: On Valid Optimal Assignment Kernels and Applications to Graph Classification

sections.text: A leading design paradigm for this is the convolution core, which splits structured objects into their parts and sums across all subpairs. However, mapping cores are obtained from an optimal bijection between parts that can provide a more valid idea of similarity. However, in general, optimal mappings result in indeterminate functions, making their use in core methods more difficult. We characterize a class of base cores that are used to compare parts that guarantee positive semidefinitive optimal mappings cores. These base cores result in hierarchies from which the optimal mappings cores are calculated in linear time by cutting histograms. We apply these results by developing the Weisfeiler-Lehman optimal mappings core for graphs. It provides high classification accuracy on widely used benchmark data sets that improve on the original Weisfeiler-Lehman kernel.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The various existing methods for combinatorial optimization have been successfully applied to any type of data for which a kernel is available, which adequately measures the similarity between the two data objects. (This also applies to the way in which the different types of data objects are found in the different areas of the real and real world.) There are many graphics that can be considered as instances of the entanglement of kernels. (It is the way in which the different approaches between the individual parts of the concept of kernels and the different types of entanglement are considered.) (In fact, many graphical kernels can be considered as instances of the entanglement of kernels under different decompositions.) It is possible to assign the parts of one object to the other parts so that the similarity between the parts is total that the parts assigned to the parts is possible.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: Before proceeding with our contribution, we begin with the introduction of a key notation for cores and trees that will be used later. A (valid) kernel on a set of X is a function k: X · X → R, so that there is a real Hilbert space H and a figure φ: X → H, so that k (x, y) = < φ (x) > is a function for all x, y in X, where < ·, · > denotes the inner product of H. We call φ a feature card, and H a feature space. Likewise, a function k: X · X → R is a kernel, if and only if for each subset {x1,..., xn} X the n × n matrix defined by [m] i, j = k (xi, xj) is a feature space. The Dirac kernel kм is a kernel, if and only if for each subset {x1,} X is the n × n matrix defined by [m] i, j = k (xi, xj).

sections.heading: 3 Strong kernels and hierarchies
sections.text: In this section, we will introduce a limited class of kernels that will later lead to valid, optimal mappings (most kernels are used as base kernels); we will provide two distinct characterizations of this class, one based on an imbalance of kernel values, and the other in the form of a hierarchy defined on the domain of the kernel, which will provide the basis for our algorithms to calculate valid, optimal mappings. We will first consider similarity functions that meet the requirement for any two objects that are more similar than the two; we will see later in Section 3.1 that each such function is actually p.s.d. and hence is a valid hierarchy. Definition 1 (Strong Kernel) A function k: X × X → R is referred to as strong kernels when k (x, y) is referred to as strong class.

sections.heading: 3.1 Feature maps of strong kernels
sections.text: We use the property that each strong kernel is caused by a hierarchy to derive feature vectors for strong nuclei. Let (T, w) be a hierarchy on X that causes the strong kernel. sections.heading: 5 Graph kernels from optimal assignments
sections.text: In this section, we apply our results to obtain new graph nuclei, i.e. nuclei of the form K: G · G → R, where G denotes the set of graphs. We assume that each vertex v has a categorical designation given by τ (v). Labels typically arise from applications, e.g. in a graph representing a chemical compound, where the labels may indicate atomic types.

sections.heading: 5.1 Optimal assignment kernels on vertices and edges
sections.text: The vertex of optimal mapping kernel (V-OA) is defined as K (G, H) = KkB (V (G), V (H)), where k is the Dirac kernel on vertex points. Similarly, the optimal mapping of the kernel edge (E-OA) is given by K (G, H) = KkB (E (G), where we define k (uv, st) = 1 if at least one of the mappings (u 7 → s, v 7 → t) and (u 7 → t, v 7 → s) represent corners only with the same label; and 0 otherwise. Since these basic cores are Dirac cores, they are strong and therefore V-OA and E-OA are valid cores.

sections.heading: 5.2 Weisfeiler-Lehman optimal assignment kernels
sections.text: Weisfeiler-Lehman cores are based on iterative vertex color refinement and have demonstrated that they provide state-of-the-art prediction performance in experimental assessments [17]. These cores use the classic one-dimensional Weisfeiler-Lehman heuristics to test graph isomorphisms and observe sub-tree patterns that encode the neighborhood of each vertex up to a certain distance. For parameters h and a graph G with initial labels, a sequence (τ0,.) of refined labels called colors is calculated, τ0 = process and process for quantifying the quantity L − 1 is determined by the following method: Sort the multicolor G with initial labels (u): vu-E (G)} for each vertex v lexicographically to obtain a unique sequence of colors and quantify the quantity (1) as the quantity (1) of the first element.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental evaluation
sections.text: We report on the experimental evaluation of the proposed graphene nuclei from optimal allocations and compare them with modern folding nuclei.

sections.heading: 6.1 Method and Experimental Setup
sections.text: We conducted classification experiments with the C-SVM implementation LIBSVM [6]. We report on average predictive accuracies and standard deviations achieved by 10-fold cross-validation repeated 10 times with random fold mapping. Within each fold, all necessary parameters were selected by cross-validation based on the training set, including regularization parameters C, kernel parameters where applicable and whether the core matrix needs to be normalized. All cores were implemented in Java and experiments were performed with Oracle Java v1.8.0 on an Intel Core i7-3770 CPU at 3.4 GHz (Turbo Boost disabled) with 16GB RAM using a single processor. Kernel, we implemented the Vertex kernel (V) and the edge kernel (E) that are the dose products on vertex and channel markers.

sections.heading: 6.2 Results and discussion
sections.text: The only notable exception is MUTAG. The extent of improvement compared to the other data sets varies, but is particularly noteworthy for ENZYMES and REDDIT. This suggests that optimal assignment cores for these classification tasks offer a more valid idea of similarity than folding cores. The most successful kernel is WL-OA, which almost consistently improves over WL and performs best in seven of the nine data sets. WL-OA provides the second-best accuracy in D & D and ranks in the middle for MUTAG. For these two data, the accuracy difference between the cores is small and even the best performance for seven of the nine data sets. The time to compute the square kernel matrix was less than one minute for all cores, with the time between the cores D and DLAB (the optimal time for the lead time of DLAS 29 and DLAS) being the fastest.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: We have characterized the class of strong cores that leads to valid, optimal assignment cores and have derived novel, effective cores for graphs from them. Reduction to histogram intersections makes efficient1The datasets, further references and statistics can be found at https: / / ls11-www.cs.uni-dortmund. de / staff / morris / graphkerneldatasets.computation and well-known acceleration techniques for intersections can be applied directly (see e.g. [19] and references therein). We believe that our results can form the basis for the design of new cores that can not only be efficiently calculated, but also adequately measure similarity.

Most kernels for structured data decompose both objects and add up the pairwise similarities between their parts following the seminal concept of convolution kernels proposed by Haussler [11].
In fact, many graph kernels can be seen as instances of convolution kernels under different decompositions [21].

Grauman and Darrell proposed the pyramid match kernel that seeks to approximate correspondences between points in R by employing a space-partitioning tree structure and counting how often points fall into the same bin [10].
An adaptive partitioning with non-uniformly shaped bins was used to improve the approximation quality in high dimensions [9].
[7] proposed kernels for graphs derived from an optimal assignment between their vertices and applied the approach to molecular graphs.
However, it was shown that the resulting similarity measure is not necessarily a valid kernel [20].

[14] considered the problem of finding optimal assignments between multiple sets.
This approach was referred to as transitive assignment kernel in [16] and employed for graph classification.
Various general approaches to cope with indefinite kernels have been proposed, in particular, for support vector machines (see [13] and references therein).
While the computation reduces to histogram intersection similar to the pyramid match kernel [10], our approach is in no way restricted to specific objects like points in R.
Indeed, every ultrametric can be embedded into a Hilbert space [12] and thus the associated inner product is a valid kernel.

metadata.abstractText: The success of kernel methods has initiated the design of novel positive semidefinite functions, in particular for structured data. A leading design paradigm for this is the convolution kernel, which decomposes structured objects into their parts and sums over all pairs of parts. Assignment kernels, in contrast, are obtained from an optimal bijection between parts, which can provide a more valid notion of similarity. In general however, optimal assignments yield indefinite functions, which complicates their use in kernel methods. We characterize a class of base kernels used to compare parts that guarantees positive semidefinite optimal assignment kernels. These base kernels give rise to hierarchies from which the optimal assignment kernels are computed in linear time by histogram intersection. We apply these results by developing the Weisfeiler-Lehman optimal assignment kernel for graphs. It provides high classification accuracy on widely-used benchmark data sets improving over the original Weisfeiler-Lehman kernel.
